newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish growth could exceed forecast - fin ministry.
newsitem.headline: Swedish growth could exceed forecast - fin ministry.

text.p: Sweden's economy could grow faster than forecast in the supplementary budget with the forecasts for 1998 more pessimistic than optimistic, the Finance Ministry said on Wednesday.

"I have a feeling that things could go a bit better next year than we have forecast, assuming there won't be any extra disturbance that affects the economy, such as something about EMU," ministry spokesman Anders Palmer told a press seminar.
Palmer said he based his belief on improved exports.
"Exports can be better than we estimated and this would improve Gross Domestic Product and the Swedish economy," said Palmer.
In the supplementary budget released on Tuesday, the minority Social Democratic government forecast GDP rising 2.3 percent in 1997 and 2.5 percent next year, compared to 1.1 percent in 1996.
It forecast exports rising 6.3 percent in 1997 and 5.8 percent in 1998, compared to 5.6 percent in 1996.
The Consumer Price Index (December-December) was forecast to rise 1.8 percent in 1997, 1.5 percent in 1998, and two percent in 1999 and 2000.
